models.overview: This file defines which models to use for each agent role. The orchestrator reads this file to determine model assignments. These are defaults — the orchestrator may escalate to a higher-tier model when a lower-tier agent fails or encounters complexity beyond its capability. The planner's complexity rating can also override the default tier at dispatch time (see dispatch-override section).

tiers.tier: Planning, review, debugging, escalation, team coordination.
Simple/mechanical implementation — renames, moves, boilerplate, admin operations.

roles.role: Never writes code, documentation, or runs commands. Human interface and workflow coordinator only. Launches sub-agents and manages workflow progression. During IMPLEMENTATION, acts as Agent Team lead: creates branches, spawns implementation teammates, monitors progress, and handles escalation directly.

Explores codebase and project documentation to build context for planning. Reads code AND docs, but treats code as the source of truth — docs may be outdated. When docs contradict code, flags the discrepancy in the context report. Read-only — never writes code or documentation.
Drafts implementation plans from tickets. Assigns complexity ratings (light / standard / complex) per sub-task that determine model tier at dispatch.
Reviews plans, raises questions to human via orchestrator.
Writes code. Escalates on failure after 1 retry. See escalation-rules for the full failure protocol that must be included in agent instructions.
Boilerplate, renames, simple edits. Escalates on any failure.
Reviews git changes against existing documentation to determine if updates are needed. Triages: no changes, trivial fix, or full audit required. Read-only — never writes code or documentation.
Performs deep per-file documentation audit. Produces structured findings with severity ratings and suggested fixes. Read-only — never writes.
Applies approved documentation updates. Only modifies documentation files. Operates in the DOCS workflow — failures escalate directly to the orchestrator.
Compiles commits and diffs to draft pull request title, summary, changes table, and AI suggested testing plan. Read-only — never writes code or documentation.

Performs administrative git and GitHub operations: push branches, create PRs via gh, close beads tickets. No code or documentation changes. Operates in the PR workflow — failures escalate directly to the orchestrator.

models.dispatch-override:
The planner assigns a complexity rating to each sub-task during the PLANNING workflow. The orchestrator (team lead) uses this rating to select the model tier for each implementation teammate at dispatch:
Haiku. Boilerplate, renames, simple mechanical edits.
Sonnet. Normal implementation work.
Opus. Known-complex sub-tasks that would likely fail and escalate anyway.
The escalation path still applies regardless of starting tier. A complex task dispatched at reasoning that fails will escalate to the orchestrator for human guidance.

section.name: implementation-agents
section.description: For worker and light tier agents (implementer, light-implementer) operating as Agent Team teammates under the orchestrator (team lead). This protocol MUST be included in every teammate's instructions.
section.rule: If you encounter an error, retry once with a different approach.

The orchestrator (team lead) classifies your failure: - Technical failures (logic bugs, command errors, test failures): an Opus (reasoning tier) teammate is spawned with your failure context to attempt resolution. - Requirements failures (impossible plan, unclear spec, wrong direction): the human is asked for clarification or course correction. You do not need to handle this — just report and stop.
If the Opus escalation teammate also fails on a technical issue, the orchestrator presents the problem to the human for guidance.

section.name: doc-workflow-agents
section.description: For doc-writer agents operating in the DOCS workflow. Doc-writers report directly to the orchestrator.
section.rule: If you encounter an error, retry once with a different approach.
If the retry fails, stop immediately. Return a structured failure report directly to the orchestrator.
The orchestrator presents the failure to the human for guidance.

section.name: admin-agents
section.description: For the submitter agent operating in the PR workflow. The submitter reports directly to the orchestrator.
section.rule: If a git or GitHub operation fails (e.g. push rejected, gh pr create fails), stop immediately and report the error to the orchestrator.
The orchestrator presents the failure to the human for guidance.

section.name: reasoning-agents
section.description: For reasoning tier agents (explorer, planner, plan-reviewer, doc-scout, doc-auditor, pr-drafter). These are already at the highest tier.
section.rule: If a reasoning-tier agent fails, it reports the failure back to the orchestrator.
The orchestrator presents the failure to the human for guidance.

models.overrides: To change model assignments for a specific project, edit the roles section above. For example, a budget-conscious project might set implementer to light tier with escalation to worker then reasoning.
